awd_titl_txt: Development of Community Light Scattering Computational Capabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
This study seeks to develop theoretical and computational methods to improve simulations of optical properties of non-spherical particles over a broad range of size parameters.  Applications of the theoretical/computational work span many broad areas of physics, chemistry, and engineering; with specific importance in atmospheric and oceanic sciences, combustion science, astrophysics, bio-optics, manufacturing diagnostics and control, and many other fields.  This study will train graduate students and post-doctoral scholars.  After testing and optimization, this research group plans to release the computational programs as open-source codes to the research community. 

This study seeks to expand previous NSF-funded research to develop advanced capabilities based on the invariant imbedding T-matrix method (II-TM) for simulating the optical properties of non-spherical, inhomogeneous particles with small to moderate size parameters.  This study seeks to further improve the II-TM from both theoretical and numerical perspectives.  This group recently developed a preliminary version of a physical geometric optics model (PGOM) based on either an electromagnetic volume- or a surface-integral relation for large size parameters.  The suite of PGOM and II-TM will represent state-of-the-art light scattering computational capabilities, with a wide range of applications in atmospheric/oceanic radiative transfer and remote sensing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF project entitled “Development of Community Light Scattering Computational Capabilities,” awarded to Texas A&M University, improved the efficiency and accuracy of the invariant imbedding T-matrix method (IITM) and the physical geometric optics method (PGOM) and achieved a synergistic combination of the IITM and PGOM for light scattering computations. In particular, this project was mainly focused on a) improving the IITM in terms of its accuracy and efficiency for light scattering computations involving particles of small-to-moderate sizes, b) improving the PGOM in terms of its accuracy and efficiency for light scattering computations involving particles of moderate-to-large sizes, and c) achieving a synergistic combination of IITM and PGOM to compute the single-scattering properties of dielectric particles of all sizes. Clearly documented IITM and PGOM computational programs have been released to the research community via the project principal investigator’s webpage at Texas A&M University. Other accomplishments were related to utilizing IITM and PGOM to understand various physical processes in light scattering and generate optical property datasets for downstream applications in remote sensing implementations and radiative transfer simulations. The scientific advancements achieved through this project are anticipated to improve light scattering simulations. The outcomes of this project lead to seven peer-reviewed journal publications. In addition, two manuscripts are under review.
